abstract:
This text describes a method for detecting and measuring cyanotoxins, which are harmful substances produced by certain types of cyanobacteria during harmful algal blooms (cyanoHAB). The presence of these blooms and their toxins can pose risks to both human contact recreation and aquatic life. To help manage these risks, the California Cyanobacterial and Harmful Algal Bloom Network (CCHAB) provides guidance on responding to and closing public access to waterbodies when toxin concentrations reach danger levels.

The method explains that there are different types of cyanotoxins, such as microcystin, anatoxin-a, and cylindrospermopsin, and various congeners (chemical variants) of each toxin. For initial screening and quantifying the presence of these toxins in larger amounts, Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) can be used as it can detect common chemical structures shared by multiple congeners. However, for more precise and lower concentration measurements of specific cyanotoxin congeners, Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry/Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) is recommended.

The method advises that when collecting samples for cyanotoxin analysis, it's essential to consider which analytical method and laboratory are best suited based on the requirement of measuring a single congener or a group of congeners for each cyanotoxin. This comprehensive approach helps ensure effective monitoring, detection, and mitigation of risks associated with harmful algal blooms and their toxins.

Here's the non-technical focus overview in simpler terms:

The text discusses a method for detecting harmful substances called cyanotoxins produced by certain types of blue-green algae during harmful algal blooms (cyanoHAB). These blooms can pose risks to humans and aquatic life, so the California Cyanobacterial and Harmful Algal Bloom Network provides guidance on how to respond when toxin concentrations become dangerously high.

There are different types of cyanotoxins, like microcystin, anatoxin-a, and cylindrospermopsin, and various chemical variants (congeners) of each toxin. For initial screening and measuring larger amounts of these toxins, Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) can be used. This method can detect common structures shared by multiple congeners. However, for more detailed and lower concentration measurements of specific cyanotoxin congeners, Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry/Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) is preferred.

When taking samples for cyanotoxin analysis, it's important to choose the appropriate analytical method and laboratory based on whether you need to measure a single congener or multiple congeners for each cyanotoxin, ensuring effective monitoring and risk management in relation to harmful algal blooms.
description:
This text discusses the risks associated with cyanobacterial harmful algal blooms (cyanoHAB) and the presence of cyanotoxins in water bodies. The text mentions specific cyanobacterial species such as Microcystis, Dolichospermum, Aphanizomenon, and Pseudoanabaena, which can produce toxins when their chlorophyll-a density reaches certain levels (13-25 g/L). The California Cyanobacterial and Harmful Algal Bloom Network (CCHAB) provides guidance for environmental and public health managers in response to cyanoHABs based on action levels for various cyanotoxins.

The text lists three types of cyanotoxins - Microcystin, Anatoxin-a, and Cylindrospermopsin - along with their respective action levels (Caution: 0.86-20 g/L, Warning: 20-90 g/L for Tier I, Danger: >90 g/L for Tier II). It's important to note that each of these toxins has multiple chemical congeners, which can be grouped and measured together using techniques like Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) based on common chemical structures. For instance, ADDA amino acid side chain is a common structure among microcystin congeners, making it suitable for ELISA quantification.

Additionally, the text discusses Liquid Chromatography-Mass Spectrometry/Mass Spectrometry (LC-MS/MS) as an analytical method that can quantify specific chemical congeners of a cyanotoxin at lower concentrations. To summarize, when collecting samples for cyanotoxin analysis, choose an appropriate analytical method and laboratory based on the requirement to measure a single congener or a group of congeners for each cyanotoxin.
